no problem @drolando!
excellent suggestions @jorgheymans

We've recently had this concern again in Brave, where client-side host/authority tag could be handy https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/issues/950

I'd kind of like to just land this soon as it seems most agree a client-side tag referring to this data is already in use. So, this is more a formalization effort.

We could consider a tag "server.host/name", which could be more general (for RPC and MySQL) too...
* the HTTP "host" header
* the authority of the URL
* the SNI server name presented during the SSL handshake by the client.

This wouldn't prevent an additional/alternative tag for "http.authority/host", just be
more general purpose for CLIENT/PRODUCER spans (for RPC and MySQL) too.

Using the word "server" allows people to see this is the client point of view, and could
help avoid data problems where otherwise someone might tag a SERVER span incorrectly.

While "server.host" or "server.name" isn't perfect (ex it *should* be "broker.host" in
messaging), I think that partial nuance can be cleared up in docs.

For value validation, we can say that this is not an IP address, rather to use remoteEndpoint for that.
However, we'd probably end up with port info here, as that's a natural component of URL authority.

Thoughts?

To punt a specific plan of action. 👍 this comment if you want the following. reply back if you want something different instead!

define "server.host" tag with only the host (not the port part) as defined on the client side. This should be tagged on CLIENT spans where possible. IP address isn't valid, and should be avoided, mentioning to use remoteEndpoint.ip for that instead.

We choose to not explicitly define "http.host", though people can surely use that as they do now. By not defining "http.host" formally, we encourage more re-use of "server.host"

One tag, "server.host", for the client side will help RPC, HTTP and broker type communications, and be less complex to search and cheaper to index vs two similar ones.
In effort to reduce the open PRs, I'm going to merge this and feel free to revise later. Thanks @anuraaga

I appreciate you raising this, and one outcome was that we have better docs. That said, the change as proposed won't be merged, so let's close it and move on. Cheers

https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/blob/master/instrumentation/RATIONALE.md#why-does-the-client-response-callback-run-in-the-invocation-context

sorry about the late comment. @shakuzen's note was asking about if data would be valid if there's no timestamp based on the notes in our docs about it. It is still invalid, but the trace should render.

we've had users think that because our data format permits certain fields like localEndpoint and timestamp to be absent, that means the data is valid. It isn't valid, but there's a different question about whether the UI should crash (shouldn't) or what the UI should do about it (skip or backfill based on some heuristic)

The reason it can be confusing is that spans can be reported twice. ex `span.flush()` followed by `span.finish()`. There are 2 json in this case and span-cleaner in lens will merge those as one. This means that if one or the other has a timestamp, we are fine.

Spans that never started are a bug, in other words. Spans reported twice are not necessarily a bug. In any case a missing timestamp shouldn't crash the UI for the trace.

Given this, should we merge the change?

cc @jorgheymans as being the issue-master this topic is an important and frequently misunderstood one. I'm even thinking about finding a place in our openapi docs to double or triple underscore that nullability of a field does not imply it is good data to leave it out. Somehow we need to clearly say that "patching" a span can happen and in that case, consider the merged data when thinking of how to interpret fields.
I'm going to close this issue as it helps the team focus on issues to progress. We can re-open it if it becomes actionable with new information, more hands, more demand. Thanks folks!

Since the model is so simple, and also so stable, I think the best way forward is a pipeline-specific mutable type vs more coupling. In the domain of a pipeline, very efficient (more efficient than ours!) codecs can be used. Also, the functions can match up to the transformation libraries (ex kafka streams etc).

I don't expect us to make the zipkin span mutable, so I'll close this instead of leaving it open without an answer. Here's the closest we have at the moment, which may work for those disinterested in using jackson etc. https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-reporter-java/tree/master/brave

I earlier made a comment that a conservative approach (making remoteService dependent on service) would allow things to progress until we had demand for the latter https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1794#issuecomment-481482792 

Recently, #2999 was opened to allow search solely by remote service name. If you desire this, upvote it

I'm starting to wonder if an indexconfig type wouldn't be helpful, because right now, we have the following indexes:
 * serviceName
 * spanName
 * remoteServiceName
 * annotations (non-core implicitly, ex not "cs" "sr" etc)
 * tags (including auto-complete controlled by key name)
 
In all cases, these are keywords, so in java a keyword based predicate could be used.

Ex. 
 * KeywordFilter.NONE (disable annotation indexing)
 * KeywordFilter.SHORT (<256 characters, which is the current constraint)
 * KeywordFilter.in(list) (would match auto-complete tags)

While I mention this in java, the above could map to properties or a json struct. In any case a structure could allow disabling certain things like spanName (as requested by @mrajah-twttr) or controlling remoteServiceName (as requested by @drolando).

In any case, we'd have the chance to disable annotation indexing which has proven itself probably more burden than ever helpful. For example, we've never had a means to disable keyword searching for annotations, and doing this could easily add useless load when tools like open-telemetry start adding more annotations than we'd use or expect.

For example, OpenTelemetry [events](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-specification/blob/6f47d037b52a9892570a0b0964d6b12f5891a0a3/specification/trace/api.md#add-events) literally [embed json in the annotation name](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-specification/blob/5aae909967a6ed9d716755427eecc4c6d5f80181/specification/trace/sdk_exporters/zipkin.md#events), but still could be under the 255 char limit adding load to c* and elastic. This is not unlike problems we had in OpenTracing

Concretely, this literal example OpenTelemetry use would end up indexed in ES or Cassandra:
`"my-event-name": { "key1" : "value1", "key2": "value2" }`


So in short, it might make sense to create a keyword based struct, which at least allows disabling annotations as currently we should expect to see much more low-value load caused by OpenTelemetry otherwise.

cc @openzipkin/core
thanks for the look @anuraaga and @jorgheymans!

I think we should look at existing loggers (like zipkin2.collector which
logs errors at debug) and also the more detailed Prometheus metrics first
before adding a new variable and another custom thing.

Probably we can add some notes about the general process of troubleshooting
which is more metrics first.

When the issue was discussed on chat 100pct of spans were dropped. with an
always log errors thing it would be dumping errors into the console at the
rate of traffic which is a reason why we dont do this.

On Wed, Jun 24, 2020, 10:57 PM Simon Dean <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *Feature:*
> Zipkin Server includes a ES_HTTP_LOGGING setting to configure logging for
> Zipkin Server's HTTP requests to Elasticsearch. The setting can be set to:
> BASIC, HEADERS, BODY. By default, the logging is not enabled.
>
> The feature request is to add a new logging level that only logs errors
> with communicating with Elasticsearch and to make it the default value, so
> error logging is enabled by default.
>
> *Rational*
> By default, Zipkin Server does not log an errors with communicating with
> Elasticsearch. This feature request would change that.
>
> *Example Scenario*
> This feature would be used whenever there's an issue with Zipkin
> communicating with Elasticsearch in order to find out what the root cause
> is.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/3128>, or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAAPVV3WW27GBAYQZ3WIVA3RYIH6DANCNFSM4OGX4FDQ>
> .
>

Also, typically the easiest way to see an error that causes 100pct to drop is to hit the /health endpoint which would include error details in such case. It isn't always the same though. Main idea is I think we can put some docs in zipkin-server/README for the general troubleshooting case (ex /health /metrics /promethus generic loggers), then whatever exists in the storage specific are available also.

I'm not sure everyone knows that errors are logged already, or that /health might show why also, in other words

Unless you still feel strong about this i'ld say we scratch this one off the list. The parameters are what they are and have been for quite a while now, i have looked at the issues list and did not see any support issues complaining about it.

About `lookback` not being camelcase, https://github.com/search?l=Java&q=lookback&type=Code suggests that there is no consensus really and everybody does as they see fit so we're certainly not in the wrong.

Even though there is a lot of useful mysql tuning info in this issue, i'm going to go ahead and close it based on the fact that mysql storage is no longer considered "for production usage" and mostly exists "to help aid transition to supported ones" (see https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-server#mysql-storage). Given that, write performance improvements are not likely to be implemented by the core team in the foreseeable future.

As always, if your site is bothered by this feel free to dive in the technical details and raise a PR it will definitely be considered !

Is the thrift-less Cassandra scheme not this https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-storage/cassandra (as opposed to the older, thrift-ful one here https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-storage/cassandra-v1) ?

If yes then we're good to close this (and #1008 as well most likely)

Hi! thanks for helping. I wonder what is your motivation.

Yes, should be useful for viewing the full name for services that have long names. An example screenshot
makes sense. @openzipkin/ui anyone have other ideas on how to handle long service names? I admit I've also wondered about this.
thanks as always @anuraaga

OK I went ahead and finished the un-guava'ing which made the TraceIdIndexerTest a good bit larger than before. So, after this, we can move to Datastax 4 which can get rid of the last of it (ListenableFuture -> CompletableFuture which we can't do w/o v4).

BTW this is part of a bigger change around time-based indices that will lead to [data streams](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/master/data-streams.html); though that is still work in progress. So I would wait a little longer here and see if that might make sense for Zipkin as well.

I see... 👍
are you actually using collector sample rate? it is a barely used feature and if it isn't set, they would never be dropped due to sampling..
yes I recently introduce it due to storage overload, I thought most people use that feature..

the problem with it is that it requires uniform trace IDs or may not consistently drop a trace and isn't really surge protected (as it is an mask not a rate) 

Another way, if you are controlling the image, is meanwhile put a metric in CollectorSampler then you can see that and know how many are from this. If you find this is useful, we can pick this change back up?

> Another way, if you are controlling the image, is meanwhile put a metric in CollectorSampler then you can see that and know how many are from this. If you find this is useful, we can pick this change back up?

You mean implement CollectorSampler and add metrics into custom sampler?
It's a good idea, but I still think split storage error and sampled out metrics is reasonable. And for users are not setting sample-rate, they will still get the same metrics with same number with my change.

just this is a api break, so since almost no one uses this feature are breaking and it will add a zero count metric in prometheus because as far as I know micrometer will add metrics eagerly even if never incremented...

otoh custom collectors are also not common, and we can train people to ignore this.

for example, I don't think we'd ever even add collector sampling as it exists today if it was never there in the old thrift thing.

main issue is this is breaking api and adding distracting stuff over something that isn't used often and is also not a very good flow control strategy

for background, and really we should have never implemented what you are using right now.. this thing was only used by twitter and only for zookeeper managed rate.. a flat rate collector side doesn't do flow control in any helpful way. the sample rate in config was the "initial rate" which would change.  https://github.com/openzipkin-attic/zipkin-zookeeper

and that ZK thing had its own metrics also. It would be a lesser api break to make a factory for CollectorSampler like we do for CollectorMetrics, which would use the same keys... in fact it is probably not even an api break.

wdyt?

one neat thing if we did the factory approach is that we can add metrics only if someone actually set the rate to something also.. we just wrap it and make it an internal thing in the server config. Ex. CollectorSampler.Factory is injected.. by default it returns a NOOP.. no metrics no nothing. If the spring config is set, then the thing internally adds a metric (I assume you want prometheus anyway, not /metrics endpoint, but even that could be done)

That would make sure it doesn't drift our other collectors like in zipkin-aws or anything people have.

WDYT?
i see, so for many reasons, I agree that the PR may not be exposed to normal end-user.

@anuraaga I tried to fix the comments. PTAL
thanks for the look and advice @anuraaga!

Thank you for feedback! @jorgheymans 

> * when manually clearing spanName , it should reappear in the list:

Sorry. I couldn't reproduce it.
Maybe it has been fixed in the latest commit 🤔 

> * the empty criteria box seems an invalid state, but i'm not sure how to reproduce it consistently:

The criteria box is synchronized with the query parameter.
If the query parameter has an empty criterion, an empty criteria box will be displayed.
For example, if the query parameter is `?serviceName=serviceA&=&spanName=spanA`, then the criteria boxes will be as follows:

![スクリーンショット 2020-07-13 13 41 26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/87271786-43268280-c50f-11ea-9d94-180fe196fbff.png)

I could not reproduce generating this empty criterion from the UI by normal way.
Maybe this has been fixed in the latest commit...

> * if you don't select a value for service name and click outside of the widget it stays like this. Not sure if intended ?

About autocompleteKeys, it is an intended behavior.
This is because autocompleteKeys will eventually be converted to annotationQuery, so criterion without value are sufficient.

But for all other keys(serviceName, spanName, ...), value is needed.
So I'll fix it.

> * I noticed some suspicious behaviour pressing reload in the browser, and using 'back' button to go from trace screen back to search overview it may be in play when state gets corrupted not sure.

hmmm...I could not reproduce it... 🤔 

> * Should the search button go next to the 'limit' field to reduce mouse travel ? Or make it more clear somehow that ctrl-enter does the same thing.

Now, if you press enter when the criteria box is not focused, searching will start 👍

Supporting custom lookback in the form seems nice, but I'm more concerned with the default lookback parameter, like here

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-server/src/main/java/zipkin2/server/internal/ui/ZipkinUiConfiguration.java#L141

There was code specifically dealing with a milliseconds lookback that could come from that flag before but I can't find it in the new version, can you point me at it? AFAIK that flag can be any millliseconds, not our fixed lookbacks.
I got it 🙇
Secured Zipkin's UI using Proxy server.

Also sorry about being late, i'ld say merge this in pending this comment https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2926#discussion_r348915149 . 

About making this clear in the openapi docs, I don't think this will buy us much. Having a trace diagnostic tool somewhere that is able to tell if a trace is more or less as we expect it or not, what is wrong, what we can compensate in the UI etc would be more helpful. It's along these lines https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1484 , but i'm more thinking a separate endpoint where you would upload a trace or give it the id of a trace that isn't showing and it spits out the diagnostics.

this looks very cool.thanks for taking the time to redo this. 

i got a chance to play around with the new experience and noticed a couple of issues
1. if you search by service name and then you try to edit the box and remove all the content (quick way to clear the service name you entered) the "servicename" option is not present any more in suggested options (i see spanName and other options which are assuming service name is present)? does it make sense to keep search criteria and search text in separate text boxes instead of a single text box with servicename=<abcdservice>? i think this is the same issue jorgheymans noted
2. does it make sense to not have the user click on the + on load and open up with  the  the first search box ready to be filled.
3. i believe this is an issue even in existing UI but when you start typing the service name the characters dont show up right away until the lookahead is returned making it feel like a hang at times. since we are in the same code base would be great if we can fix it?

overall i see this as a nice way forward, excited to push it to our customers when it lands.
This appears to be resolved in 2.21.5.

Fixes #1370

> we should close this issue with a pull request updating zipkin/zipkin-collector/kafka/README.md with notes on how to achieve best performance. there are some notes here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Px44fjZ37gr05lV7UFo8AfrWZCcJHCuv58290XCbDaw/edit#bookmark=id.eeozlmh0fxr

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3152 addressed this. If there are any other expert-level tweaks sites had success with we'ld be glad to hear them !
This will be fixed by https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3076 when it lands.

Kafka will only hand you the messages as fast as you can receive them, so indeed, if backpressure is ever needed we could make a blocking version of the collector. 

> There's a problem we might have, which is that kafka marks slow consumers dead (I hear).

Indeed, this refers to https://kafka.apache.org/documentation/#max.poll.interval.ms . Default value is 5 minutes though, if the storage write from the latest message poll did not complete within 5 minutes you have other issues mkay.

I'm going to out on a limb and close this discussion for now. There was no conclusion which approach is more beneficial, and it's been four years since so we can assume that the current approach works good enough for most sites. Incidentally, work is being done by Grand Moft Cole to upgrade the Cassandra driver to 4.0 (https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3154 and others), but i doubt this will have any consequences for this discussion. 

If anybody still wants to get into the fine details on this feel free to reopen and provide the hard numbers.

Closing as this mostly concerns activity outside of the Zipkin project itself. It seems to have been implemented at some point as Ser Cole points out here https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1251#issuecomment-253697072 and here https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1251#issuecomment-262125630 . If anything should still be done inside of Zipkin itself to facilitate or improve this feel free to open a new issue.

Note: I chose to not affect the Kafka defaults which are massively chatty in the console. This is because not everyone uses Kafka, and also as it has more state, it is possible some lines there hold value. Another PR to reduce Kafka chattiness would be welcome, though!
